facts.text: Appellant convicted under r.6(a) of the Indian Passport Rules, 1950, and sentenced to fine of Rs. 100 by Presidency Magistrate 16th Court, Esplanade, Bombay, in Criminal Case No. 1913/P of 1955 on January 3, 1956.
Bombay High Court in Criminal Application for Revision No. 278 of 1956 upheld conviction but reduced sentence to Rs. 25 on July 4, 1957, and granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.
Appellant is a citizen of India.
Appellant entered territories of India without a passport.
Appellant entered India sometime after February 15, 1954 (date of Supreme Court judgment in Ebrahim Vazir Mavat v. State of Bombay) and before February 26, 1955.
Appellant went to Karachi for the first time on November 19, 1948, but movements during this period not relevant.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.3 of the Indian Passport Act, 1920 and r.3 of the Indian Passport Rules, 1950 are ultra vires the Constitution insofar as they affect the right of an Indian citizen to enter India without a passport, offending Art.19(1)(d) and (e).
Whether s.3 of the Act and r.3 of the Rules apply to Indian citizens or only to non-Indian citizens.

petitioner_arguments.text: s.3 of the Act and r.3 of the Rules are ultra vires the Constitution insofar as they relate to Indian citizens, offending Art.19(1)(d) and (e), subject only to reasonable restrictions under Art.19(5).
On proper interpretation, s.3 of the Act and r.3 of the Rules apply only to non-Indian citizens.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.3 Indian Passport Act, 1920; r.3 Indian Passport Rules, 1950

petitioner_arguments.text: Case involves substantial question of constitutional interpretation requiring reference to Constitution Bench of five judges under Art.145(3).

court_reasoning.text: Supreme Court in Ebrahim Vazir Mavat v. State of Bombay held that requiring Indian citizen returning from Pakistan to produce passport is proper restriction on entry under Art.19; only removal order was invalid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Decision binding; requiring passport for entry is valid restriction.

court_reasoning.text: No substantial question of constitutional interpretation arises as question already decided by five-judge bench; no need for Constitution Bench.

s.3 of Act uses 'persons'; r.3 uses 'no person'; r.4 exemptions (e.g., clause b for armed forces, h for Mohamedan pilgrims) apply to Indian citizens, confirming provisions apply to all persons including citizens.
Appellant's entry without passport contravened r.3, punishable under r.6(a); conviction proper.

holdings.text: Requiring Indian citizen to possess passport to enter India is valid reasonable restriction under Art.19(5).
s.3 of Indian Passport Act, 1920 and rr.3,4 of Rules apply to all persons including Indian citizens.
Entry into India without passport by Indian citizen violates r.3, punishable under r.6(a).

precedents_cited.case_name: Ebrahim Vazir Mavat v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Held requiring passport for Indian citizen returning from Pakistan is valid restriction on entry; binding on current case.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Passport Act, 1920
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers rules requiring passports for persons entering India; applies to all persons including citizens.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Passport Rules, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: r.3 prohibits entry without valid passport; r.4 lists exemptions including some for citizens; contravention punishable.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.19 guarantees movement and residence subject to reasonable restrictions; passport requirement valid; no substantial question for five judges.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld the conviction under r.6(a) of the Indian Passport Rules, 1950, confirming the appellant's entry without passport was an offence; rejected constitutional challenge and interpretation arguments.

key_quotes.text: to require an Indian citizen to produce a passport before he can be allowed to enter India may be regarded as a proper restriction upon entering India.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms validity of passport requirement as reasonable restriction under Art.19.

key_quotes.text: the words used in s. 3 of the Act and rr. 3 and 4 of the Rules make it quite clear that they apply to every person including an Indian citizen.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets provisions to include Indian citizens.
